articles.title: Research reveals why more US homeowners are at risk of losing insurance: 'Insuring properties is a gamble'
articles.author: Claire Huber
articles.summary: As the climate changes, homeowners in high-risk areas are at risk of losing their insurance policies. Nonrenewal rates in Dare County, North Carolina, where 24 hurricanes have struck since 1985, have increased from 2% in 2018 to a staggering 7% in 2023. Insurance companies invest billions of dollars into the dirty fuel industry.

articles.title: Vaporized: Study Undermines CO2 Scare as Media Screams Climate Doom
articles.author: Catherine Salgado
articles.summary: A new study out of Greece challenges the notion and term of the 'greenhouse effect' and attempts a scientific reevaluation of the carbon = climate doom narrative. The media is still insisting that we are about to die from imminent climate apocalypse, as they have been asserting for decades.

articles.title: Devastation caused by cloudbursts
articles.author: Rana Zahid Iqbal
articles.summary: According to the latest report, Pakistan has reached the number one spot on the list of countries most affected by climate change. Since the Industrial Revolution, the Earth's temperature has increased by 1.1°C. Global temperatures could increase by 3.2°C to 3.9°C by the end of this century. Pakistan contributes less than 1% to global carbon emissions, but it is bearing the worst consequences of environmental destruction.

articles.title: Keeping cool with colours
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Austrian artist Jonas Griessler covered the asphalt in the centre of Vienna with a multitude of bright colours to reduce the temperature from 31C to 20C. The project combines creativity, science and urban planning as Europe is experiencing the latest heatwave. Many European cities are choosing greenery and lighter paint to mitigate the effects of intense heat.

articles.title: Alongside the heatwave, are we seeing an early autumn in the UK?
articles.author: Georgina Rannard
articles.summary: This summer is one of the warmest since records began in 1884. It's still hot in many parts of the UK, but some tree leaves are turning yellow and blackberries are ripe in hedges. Wanda O'Connor in Cardiff has grown melons outside for the first time since she started growing food six years ago. Climate change is affecting the timings of biological events including spring and autumn.

articles.title: Great Barrier Reef suffers worst annual coral loss in 40 years
articles.summary: The Great Barrier Reef has experienced its greatest annual loss of live coral in four decades of record-keeping. The change underscores a new level of volatility on the UNESCO World Heritage Site. The world is going through its biggest – and fourth ever recorded – mass coral bleaching event on record.

articles.title: Commentary: Heatwaves and jellyfish are causing the grid to wilt
articles.author: David Fickling
articles.summary: It's getting harder to cool down in the heat, especially for thermal generators that use the heat from burning fuels or atomic decay to spin turbines and induce electrical charges. The availability of wind can decline by 30% to 50% during heatwaves in Australia, Siberia, and Europe. India has lost 19 days' worth of coal electricity since 2014 because water shortages forced shutdowns.

articles.title: Opinion: New climate report deserves to be debated
articles.author: Veronique De Rugy
articles.summary: Department of Energy released a report on climate change. It confirms that greenhouse gases are warming the planet but tempers several claims. The report's authors also find that the planet's warming is unlikely to cause as much economic damage as is commonly claimed. Even if we eliminated all U.S. emissions, it would have an 'undetectably small' effect on global temperatures.

articles.author: CALEIGH WELLS
articles.summary: According to the National Academy of Sciences, people over-assign too much importance to low-impact actions and underestimate the carbon impact of more carbon-intensive behaviors like flying or eating meat. articles.summary: New Mexico's arid climate means limited annual precipitation. Rising temperatures have led to prolonged droughts, decreased snowpack, early melting, and reduced river flows. articles.summary: The Arctic ecosystem is under stress because of anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases. Global warming in other parts of the world is affecting the Arctic region disproportionately. The rise in temperatures is 2-3 times higher than the global average, and the rise is higher the further north you go. The polar regions are losing ice and the oceans are changing rapidly. This sets up a vicious cycle, or 'Doom Loops', which can be broken by concerted mitigation strategies.

articles.title: Show the evidence; don't just say it's there

articles.title: Emissions are driving the West's worst drought in 1,200 years
articles.author: Andrei Ionescu
articles.summary: The Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO) seesaws over decades between a warm, positive phase and a cool, negative phase. Since the 1950s, human emissions explain more than half of PDO variability, while before 1950, natural swings dominated. The PDO has lingered in its negative state since the 1990s. It pushes moisture north and leaves the Southwest with less precipitation and drier air. If emissions continue on their current path, the PDO is likely to stay negative for many years. This would constrain water supplies, heighten wildfire risk, and pressure farms and cities.

articles.title: Fire Ban Alert: Darwin, Palmerston, Coomalie, Litchfield
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Fire Ban is valid from midnight to midnight on Sunday 17 August 2025. It applies to Darwin, Palmerston, Coomalie and Litchfield in the Northern Territory. No person shall light a fire or cause a fire to be lit in the open in the areas covered by the ban.

articles.title: Experts issue warning over worsening crisis that could cost millions of people their homes: 'Teetering on the brink'
articles.author: Joseph Clark
articles.summary: People are moving to escape worsening weather events such as droughts, storms, and wildfires. World Bank report predicts up to 216 million people could be displaced by 2050 because of rising temperatures and water shortages. Extreme weather is already disrupting supply chains and could cost the worldwide economy $24 trillion by 2060.

articles.title: Social housing groups flag smaller dwellings as crisis circuit breaker
articles.author: ABC Australia
articles.summary: Albany's population is skyrocketing as sea-changers flock to the region, but a crisis is brewing away from its multi-million dollar coastline, as the population is growing away from the region's multi-billion dollar coastline and away from Albany's coastline.

articles.title: Climate change in Nigeria: causes, effects, and mitigation efforts
articles.author: Our Reporter
articles.summary: Climate change is one of the most pressing challenges facing Nigeria today. It is driven by human activities, rapid population growth, urbanization, deforestation, and reliance on fossil fuels for energy. Nigeria ratified the Paris Agreement in 2015 and developed a National Climate Change Policy to guide mitigation and adaptation efforts. The government has invested in solar and wind energy, especially in rural areas.

articles.author: Jack Gramenz
articles.summary: Earthquakes of more than magnitude five occur every one to two years in Australia. There are an average of 100 quakes at magnitude three or lower recorded each year in Australia, according to the agency. The quakes are usually of a magnitude 3 or lower.

articles.title: Thousands feel shake of magnitude 5.6 earthquake
articles.author: Australian
articles.summary: Geoscience Australia registered a 5.6 magnitude earthquake near the Wrattens National Park at Kilkivan, 170km northwest of Brisbane on Saturday morning. More than 6000 'felt reports' were received within half an hour. People across Queensland, including in Brisbane, have reported their houses shaking.

articles.title: Addressing misconceptions about Climate Sensitivity research: a Response to recent Criticisms
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: In 2020, Steven Sherwood and four co-authors published a comprehensive assessment of Earth's climate sensitivity (S20). In 2022, Nic Lewis published a detailed peer-reviewed examination of S20's methodology. In 2024, Sherwood, Chris Forest and Nic Lewis wrote an opinion piece questioning whether climate sensitivity uncertainty had really been narrowed since S20. Nic Lewis has written a comment on their opinion piece.

articles.title: Arctic Glaciers Face 'Terminal' Decline As Microbes Accelerate Ice Melt
articles.author: Slashdot
articles.summary: Scientists in Svalbard warn Arctic glaciers are in "terminal" decline. Microbe-driven biological darkening is accelerating ice melt and potentially triggering major climate feedback loops. The snowpack chemistry is now different to preindustrial era snow, according to the scientists.

articles.title: Michael O'Connor: Real climate solutions are driven by real data
articles.summary: Dr. Michael Sills' claims that extreme weather events are more frequent are not supported by U.S. historical data. His list of recommended responses is sweeping, including new federal programs, expanding the Army Corps of Engineers and Naval Construction Force, forming local 'rebuilding centers' and mobilizing and training a national workforce. His grouping of wildfires under 'extreme weather events' is imprecise. Most Americans accept the evidence for global warming.

articles.title: Hurricane Erin strengthens in the Atlantic
articles.author: CBS News
articles.summary: Erin is the Atlantic Ocean's first hurricane of the season. She is currently sitting off the coast of Anguilla and gaining strength. It is the first storm of the hurricane season so far and is expected to get stronger. It's currently a Category 1 hurricane.

articles.title: Ella Emhoff suffers from ‘climate anxiety,' feels ‘disgust' at state of the world: whiney TikTok video
articles.author: Virtual Jerusalem
articles.summary: 'I experience a lot of climate anxiety, like all of us do,' Ella Emhoff ranted in a nearly rantant post on Facebook. She also wrote that she feels 'like all the people do' about the future of the planet and its climate.

articles.title: Category 5 Hurricane Erin is one of the fastest rapidly intensifying storms in Atlantic history
articles.author: News-Press Now
articles.summary: Hurricane Erin has undergone a period of rapid intensification. It is a phenomenon that has become more common in recent years as the planet warms. It's now a rare phenomenon.    - Mary Gilbert, Allison Chinchar, Rebekah Riess, Andrew Freedman, CNN.

articles.title: Hurricane Erin strengthens to 'very powerful' Category 5 storm in Caribbean
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: The compact hurricane's centre is not expected to strike land, but it threatens to dump flooding rains on the northeast Caribbean as it continues to grow larger. It is expected to become a tropical storm later this week. It's expected to make landfall on the east coast of Cuba.

articles.title: Deadly Wildfires Engulf Europe, Killing at Least Four
articles.author: Newsweek
articles.summary: The fires come amid record-high temperatures in the region. Dry landscapes and materials are fueling the fires from Greece to Portugal, which is further fueling the blazes. The fires are burning in Greece, Portugal and elsewhere in the Mediterranean Sea.

articles.summary: 78 percent of Americans believe in climate change. 35 of the 49 major tidal floods Charleston has experienced since 1921 have occurred in the past decade. China is leading the world in renewable low-carbon energy investments, investing $818 billion in 2024. Before it's too late, our leaders must take responsible action to address global climate change, writes David Whitaker.

articles.title: Giant, destructive volcanic eruption will soon bring about the end of mankind, scientists warn. No point steering now, eh?
articles.summary: The world is going to end, either by overpopulation combined with human induced global warming, a meteor strike or an event like Yellowstone blowing. A detailed geophysical study published in Nature by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) doesn't explain it very well. The solution is to send a team of hard-working, true patriot Americans into a volcano to fix the problem.

articles.title: Africa's Sahel Archives
articles.author: Wayne Campbell
articles.summary: Wayne Campbell is an educator and social commentator. He warns that women and girls in Africa's Sahel face escalating violence, poverty and oppression. He urges the international community to increase aid, hold governments accountable and challenge harmful cultural practices to protect their rights and futures.
